#Text=3. Methodology
#Text=Conventional DEA models can only consider output expansion or input contraction , but not both .

#Text=For the hotel industry , the output-oriented approach cannot distinguish between quasi-fixed inputs and variable inputs , while the input-oriented model ignores the existence of quasi-fixed inputs .
#Text=Moreover , the primary goal of tourist hotels is to expand outputs rather than to contract inputs .
#Text=The directional distance function , capable of expanding outputs and contracting inputs simultaneously , can fulfill the requirements of this study .

#Text=In addition , because they may have different national cultures , operational philosophies , and managerial modes , different types of tourist hotels ( for instance , domestic hotels and international chain hotels ) should thus own different efficiency frontiers .
#Text=A meta-frontier approach is able to measure efficiencies of decision making units ( DMUs ) associated with distinctive technologies .
#Text=3.1. Directional Distance Function
#Text=Suppose that there are H DMUs .
#Text=Each DMU employs N variable inputs and I quasi-fixed inputs to produce P outputs .
#Text=The modified directional distance production is defined as : ( 1 ) where is the technology set .
#Text=Equation ( 1 ) searches for the largest feasible expansion of output vector in the direction and the largest feasible contraction of input vector in the direction .
#Text=Note that we treat quasi-fixed input vector as fixed .
#Text=This specification not only can characterize the property of quasi-fixed inputs in the operational management of hotels , but also satisfy the request of output expansion .
#Text=Let be the optimal value of Equation ( 1 ) .
#Text=An efficient DMU corresponds to .
#Text=In other words , the technology frontier is constructed by those DMUs associated with .
#Text=Hence , the larger the value is , the farther the DMU is from the frontier .
#Text=3.2. Meta-Frontier Approach
#Text=The production possibility set T in the DEA models is generally assumed to be convex , i.e. , all DMUs belong to a single operating system .

#Text=Due to different national cultures , operational philosophies , managerial modes , etc. , domestic and foreign-owned hotels distinctly belong to different operating systems and thus the assumption of convexity may not be valid .
#Text=The meta-frontier approach allows each group to have its own group-frontier .
#Text=The meta-frontier is defined as a common boundary that envelops the group frontiers .
#Text=The technology set associated with the meta-frontier could be convex or non-convex .
#Text=We illustrate this by
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=.
#Text=Assume that there are two groups , A and B.
#Text=The frontier of group A is the line segment connecting A1 , A2 , G , and A3 .
#Text=Similarly , the frontier of group B consists of points B1 , G , B2 , and B3 .
#Text=If the technology set is non-convex , then the relevant meta-frontier is the line segment connecting A1 , A2 , G , B2 , and B3 .
#Text=It is apparent that each part of the meta-frontier belongs to at least one of the group-frontiers .
#Text=If the technology set is convex , then the relevant meta-frontier is the line segment connecting A1 , A2 , B2 , and B3 .
#Text=Convexity allows for input – output combinations beyond the boundaries of group-frontiers , such as the dot line connecting A2 and B2 .
#Text=It may imply that existing technology can upgrade through spillover and/or mutually learning among the groups for a considerable period .
#Text=In this sense , the non-convex meta-frontier is suitable for analyzing efficiency in the short run , while the convex meta-frontier may be appropriate for analysis in the long run .
#Text=We also follow the basic assumption that the quasi-fixed inputs cannot be adjusted in the short run , but they are variable in the long run .
#Text=We now describe how to incorporate the directional distance function in the meta-frontier approach .
#Text=Let be the meta-technology set that envelopes the G group frontiers such that , where is the technology set of group g , .
#Text=The directional distance function relative to the meta-technology set can be expressed as : ( 2 )
#Text=The directional distance function relative to the technology set of group g can be defined as : ( 3 )

#Text=This study applies the following approach to calculate the direction distance function for the non-convex meta-technology set : ( 1 ) calculate the direction distance function of each DMU based on the efficient frontier of group g , say , g = 1 , 2 , ... , G ; ( 2 )

#Text=Here , and are the non-radial p th output slack and the n th input slack , respectively ; is a small non-Archimedean quantity , usually .
#Text=The first constraint labeled ( 4b ) seeks the largest contraction of the n th variable input in the direction .
#Text=The constraints in ( 4c ) search for the largest expansion of the p th output in the direction .
#Text=Expression ( 4d ) holds the quasi-fixed inputs to be fixed in the short run .
#Text=Constraints ( 4e ) to ( 4g ) ensure the technology is VRS .
